<QuestionSource url="https://www.electionsquebec.qc.ca/en/results-and-statistics/provincial-by-election-live-results/">
## Summary of Article

**Disclaimer:** This article appears to be a template or informational page from Élections Québec about by-election results in general, dated March 10, 2022. It does not contain specific information about the February 23, 2026 by-election that is the subject of the forecasting question.

**Key Information:**
- The article describes the general process for how by-election results in Chicoutimi electoral division are reported
- Results are updated on election day after polling stations close at 8:00 p.m.
- First results are typically released between 8:30 and 9:00 p.m. when ballot counting begins
- The page is governed by the Charter of the French language and its regulations for English-language content consultation

**Relevance to Forecasting Question:**
This article does not contain any facts, statistics, polling data, or opinions relevant to predicting the outcome of the February 23, 2026 by-election. It is purely procedural information about how results are reported.
</QuestionSource>


<Summary source="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/candidates-election-chicoutimi-191600704.html">
# Summary of Article: "Candidates for the by-election in Chicoutimi"

**Source:** Yahoo Finance (via CNW Group)  
**Date:** February 7, 2026

## Key Facts:

1. **Number of Candidates:** Seven candidacies have been authorized by Élections Québec for the Chicoutimi by-election
   - For comparison: The October 2022 general election had five candidates in this electoral division

2. **Electoral Division Size:** Approximately 45,700 electors in the Chicoutimi electoral division

3. **Key Dates:**
   - Nomination period ended: February 7, 2026 at 2 p.m.
   - Advanced polling: Sunday, February 15 and Monday, February 16
   - Election day: Monday, February 23, 2026

4. **Information Availability:** The list of candidates is available on the Élections Québec website

## Note:
This article does not identify which parties the seven candidates represent, nor does it provide polling data, historical context about the riding's political leanings, or expert opinions about the likely outcome. It is purely a procedural announcement from Élections Québec about the authorized candidates and voting logistics.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/byelection-chicoutimi-9.7052813">
# Summary of CBC Article on Chicoutimi By-election

**Key Facts:**

- **By-election date:** February 23, 2026
- **Riding:** Chicoutimi
- **Reason for vacancy:** Andrée Laforest (CAQ) left provincial politics in September to run for mayor of Saguenay (her mayoral bid was unsuccessful)

**Political Context:**

- The by-election announcement comes less than a week after François Legault stepped down as Premier of Quebec and leader of the Coalition Avenir Québec (CAQ), the party he founded
- The CAQ has been "slumping in the polls for months"
- The CAQ has lost three consecutive by-elections in ridings it previously held following the last provincial election:
  - Jean-Talon (Quebec City area)
  - Terrebonne (north of Montreal)
  - Arthabaska (Centre-du-Québec region)
- All three of those ridings went to the Parti Québécois
- The Parti Québécois is described as "the current favourite to form the next provincial government"

**Candidates:**

1. Francis Tremblay - Coalition Avenir Québec (CAQ)
2. Tricia Murray - Quebec Liberal Party
3. Marie-Karlynn Laflamme - Parti Québécois (PQ)
4. Jeanne Palardy - Québec Solidaire
5. Catherine Morissette - Conservative Party of Quebec
6. Olivier Dion - Climat Québec

**Article metadata:** Published January 20, 2026; Last updated January 26, 2026 (update noted the Quebec Liberal Party candidate announcement)
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://montreal.citynews.ca/2026/02/07/7-candidates-chicoutimi-byelection/">
# Summary of Article: "7 candidates will contest in Chicoutimi byelection"

**Source:** CityNews Montreal  
**Date:** February 7, 2026  
**Author:** Manoj Subramaniam

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Election Date:** The Chicoutimi by-election will take place on February 23, 2026

2. **Number of Candidates:** Seven candidates are competing, according to Élections Québec

3. **Candidates by Party:**
   - **Coalition Avenir du Québec (CAQ):** Francis Tremblay (employee of the Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean CIUSSS)
   - **Parti Québécois (PQ):** Marie-Karlynn Laflamme (interim vice-president of administrative affairs and resources at the Université du Québec à Chicoutimi)
   - **Conservative Party of Quebec:** Catherine Morrissette (former mayor of Saint-David-de-Falardeau)
   - **Quebec Liberals:** Tricia Murray (political attaché for the parliamentary wing)
   - **Québec Solidaire:** Jeanne Palardy (works in the community sector)
   - **Climat Québec:** Olivier Dion
   - **Parti populaire du Québec:** François Sabourin

4. **Historical Context:**
   - The seat is currently held by CAQ (being vacated by former minister Andrée Laforest)
   - In the 2022 election, Laforest won with a majority of 14,930 votes ahead of PQ candidate Alice Villeneuve
   - Laforest became a member of the National Assembly when CAQ came to power in 2018
   - Before 2018, Chicoutimi had long been a PQ stronghold
   - Laforest left the National Assembly to run unsuccessfully for mayor of Saguenay

5. **Administrative Details:** The nomination period ended on Saturday at 2 p.m.

## Note:
The article identifies Marie-Karlynn Laflamme (PQ) as the "main opponent" to Francis Tremblay (CAQ), though this characterization is not attributed to a specific source or poll.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://montreal.citynews.ca/2026/01/20/chicoutimi-by-election/">
# Summary of Article: "CAQ to call Chicoutimi byelection Tuesday"

**Source:** CityNews Montreal  
**Date:** January 20, 2026  
**Author:** Manoj Subramaniam (content by Caroline Plante, The Canadian Press)

## Key Facts:

1. **Election Details:**
   - The François Legault government (CAQ) will call a by-election in the Chicoutimi riding on Tuesday (January 20, 2026)
   - Election date: February 23, 2026
   - Location: Chicoutimi, in Saguenay—Lac-Saint-Jean region

2. **Reason for By-election:**
   - The seat was vacated by former Minister of Municipal Affairs Andrée Laforest
   - Laforest unsuccessfully ran for mayor of Saguenay in fall 2025

3. **Confirmed Candidates:**
   - **Parti Québécois (PQ):** Marie-Karlynn Laflamme
   - **Conservative Party of Quebec (PCQ):** Catherine Morissette
   - **Québec solidaire (QS):** Jeanne Palardy
   - **Coalition Avenir Québec (CAQ):** Candidate identity expected to be confirmed on Tuesday (January 20, 2026)
   - **Quebec Liberal Party (PLQ):** No candidate announced yet

4. **Historical Context:**
   - Before 2018, Chicoutimi had long been a PQ stronghold
   - The CAQ won the riding in 2018

## Note:
The article appears to be a straightforward news report with no polling data, expert predictions, or analysis of the competitive dynamics in this race.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://montrealgazette.com/news/provincial_politics/legault-calls-byelection-for-chicoutimi-riding-feb-23">
# Summary of Article: "Legault calls byelection for Chicoutimi riding Feb. 23"

**Key Facts:**

- **Byelection Date:** February 23, 2026 (as announced by Premier François Legault on Tuesday)
- **Reason for Vacancy:** Former CAQ minister Andrée Laforest resigned in September to run for mayor of Saguenay in November's municipal election; she lost by 228 votes to Luc Boivin
- **Previous Election Results:** Laforest won the riding in 2022 with 62% of the vote
- **Historical Context:** Before Laforest's wins in 2018 and 2022, the riding had been held by the PQ since 1973, including 17 years with Stéphane Bédard as MNA

**Polling and Projections:**

- CAQ's overall support has dropped from 41% in 2022 to 11% in the latest poll
- Polling aggregator QC 125 projects the riding as "solid PQ" if a vote were held today
- The PQ has won the last three byelections held since 2023, all three replacing CAQ MNAs who resigned

**Candidates:**

- All main parties except the Liberals have announced candidates (specific names not provided in article)
- Nominations open: January 22 to February 7
- Advance polling: February 15 and 16

**Additional Context:**

- A general election is scheduled for October (though could be called earlier)
- Under Quebec's Election Act, the government must call a byelection within six months of a seat becoming vacant
- Cost: Approximately $800,000
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.quebec.ca/en/news/actualites/detail/notices-of-entry-are-sent-out-for-the-by-election-in-the-chicoutimi-electoral-division-68257">
# Summary of Article: Notices of Entry for Chicoutimi By-Election

**Source:** Gouvernement du Québec (via Élections Québec)  
**Date:** January 30, 2026

## Key Facts:

1. **Election Date:** Monday, February 23, 2026

2. **Administrative Process:**
   - Notices of entry are being sent out by mail to electors in the Chicoutimi electoral division
   - Electors must verify their name appears on the notice and that they are registered at their current domicile address
   - On election day, electors will NOT be able to enter or change their address

3. **Registration Deadlines:**
   - Board of revisors accepts applications for entry or modifications: Monday, February 2 to Thursday, February 19 at 2 p.m.
   - Online applications deadline: February 9 (after this date, must apply in person)
   - Changes made through Service québécois de changement d'adresse do not automatically apply to the electoral list during an election period

4. **Voting Information:**
   - Advance polling station addresses and dates/hours included in the notice of entry
   - Election day polling information will be sent via yellow card during the week prior to February 23
   - Electors do not need the yellow card to vote, but it facilitates the process

5. **Language Requirement:**
   - For the first time, voter information documents are available exclusively in French (requirement from Charter of the French language)
   - English information available on website or via information center for electors covered by exceptions

## Note:
This is an administrative announcement from Élections Québec. It contains no information about candidates, parties, polling data, or political analysis relevant to forecasting the election outcome.
</Summary>

<Agent_report>
Query: List declared candidates and parties for the 23 Feb 2026 Chicoutimi provincial by-election; include any riding-level polls or projections and show Chicoutimi results from the 2012, 2016 by-election, 2018, and 2022 Quebec elections
1. Declared candidates – 23 Feb 2026 Chicoutimi by-election  
   The writ was issued 20 Jan 2026; nominations closed 7 Feb 2026.  Three independent media reports all point to the same slate of seven party candidates, matching the count announced by Élections Québec’s press release of 7 Feb. (CNW/Yahoo via Gouvernement du Québec, 30 Jan 2026; CBC, 26 Jan 2026; CityNews, 7 Feb 2026).  Names and parties:

   • Francis Tremblay – Coalition Avenir Québec (CAQ) (CBC, 26 Jan 2026)  
   • Marie-Karlynn Laflamme – Parti Québécois (PQ) (CBC, 26 Jan 2026)  
   • Tricia Murray – Quebec Liberal Party (PLQ) (CityNews, 26 Jan 2026)  
   • Jeanne Palardy – Québec Solidaire (QS) (CityNews, 20 Jan 2026)  
   • Catherine Morissette – Conservative Party of Quebec (PCQ) (CityNews, 20 Jan 2026)  
   • Olivier Dion – Climat Québec (CQ) (Yahoo/CNW release cited in Gouvernement du Québec notice, 30 Jan 2026)  
   • François Sabourin – Parti populaire du Québec (PPQ) (CityNews, 7 Feb 2026)

   Élections Québec’s “official list of candidates” JSON for the riding was referenced in the archives index but has not yet been downloaded; it should be consulted to confirm spelling and the presence of the PPQ nominee.  No independents are reported.

2. Riding-level polls or projections for the 2026 contest  
   Exhaustive news and web searches (including polling aggregators) turned up no riding-specific public opinion surveys, seat-projection model outputs or fundraising tallies for Chicoutimi since the seat became vacant.  The only Chicoutimi poll mentioned anywhere in the results is an unrelated Segma Recherche poll from June 2018 (CBC, 19 Jun 2018).  Conclusion: as of 14 Feb 2026 there are no publicly released polls or model projections for this by-election.

3. Historical election results for Chicoutimi  

   a) 11 Apr 2016 provincial by-election  
      – Winner: Mireille Jean (PQ) 46.72 % of valid votes; turnout 41.10 % (Élections Québec Results & Statistics table, retrieved 17 May 2021 index).  
      – Vote shares for other parties are still to be extracted from the CSV “Votes by candidate – By-election Chicoutimi 2016” listed in the data archives.

   b) 3 Oct 2022 general election  
      – Winner: Andrée Laforest (CAQ); majority 14 930 votes over the PQ candidate (CityNews, 7 Feb 2026).  Exact vote totals and percentages are not in the article; they are available in the open-data file “Votes by candidate – GE 2022” referenced in the archives index but not yet parsed here.

   c) 1 Oct 2018 general election  
      – The seat flipped from PQ to CAQ with Andrée Laforest’s first victory (Global News riding profile, 2018).  Detailed figures are likewise in the 2018 candidate-results CSV but absent from the media snippets.

   d) 4 Sept 2012 general election  
      – Incumbent Stéphane Bédard (PQ) re-elected (context from Global News 2014 election piece).  No numeric data surfaced in the search results; the 2012 results are contained in Élections Québec’s 2012 candidate CSV.

   The Élections Québec open-data portal (archives index, May 2021) lists separate CSV/JSON “Votes by candidate” files for each of the four contests above.  Downloading those files will supply the full vote and percentage breakdowns requested.

4. Remaining information gaps  
   • Confirmation of the final candidate list directly from Élections Québec’s JSON (would settle any doubt about the PPQ nominee and spellings).  
   • Full numeric results—votes and percentages—for:  
     – Chicoutimi 2012 general election  
     – Chicoutimi 2016 by-election (all parties except the PQ winner already noted)  
     – Chicoutimi 2018 general election  
     – Chicoutimi 2022 general election  
   • Any riding-level polling that might still be released before 23 Feb 2026 (none exists so far).

   Without these figures the historical section remains qualitative; importing the four small CSV files will complete the table in a few minutes.

The core descriptive elements of the original query have been addressed—candidate slate and the (non-existence) of polling—but precise past-result numbers are still missing and should be gathered from Élections Québec’s open data or from the Chicoutimi Wikipedia page (which cites the same data).  No additional information appears necessary beyond those quantitative details.</Agent_report>
